title: Health consequences of processed food
content: Mark first briefly lays out the health consequences of processed food with a focus on the gut microbiome.

title: Environmental consequences of industrial farming
content: From there, Mark discusses the environmental consequences of industrial farming and lays out how we can affect change on the individual level, through policy and regulations, and perhaps most importantly through regenerative agriculture. Additionally, Mark talks about the potential health risks of consuming GMO foods, herbicides, and other chemicals used in industrial farming as well as the environmental consequences, such as the loss of soil, caused by those same fertilizers and methods of farming.

title: The Physiology of Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: The Impact of Stress on Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression. He also talks about the role of stress in cancer and how it can lead to chronic illness.

title: Tips for Managing Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world. He talks about the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: The negative consequences of the existing food environment
content: The majority of patients' health issues have some relationship to food. The food system is the problem, and it's because of food policies influenced by the food industry through lobbying. 11 million people die every year from eating ultra-processed food. Mark realized he had to go to the source of the problem to help his patients.

title: The main pillars making the current food environment 'toxic'
content: Food is the biggest driver of chronic disease affecting six out of 10 people. It's also the biggest driver of economic stress in the country, with one third of all Medicare expenses for diabetes alone. The food system is the number one cause of climate change, causing massive environmental degradation and leading to political instability. It's driving social injustice and cognitive behavioral issues, and even threatens national security. All these issues are connected by food and can be solved by fixing the food system.

title: What makes processed food so unhealthy?
content: Processed food is unhealthy because it's ultra-processed and contains high levels of sugar, salt, and unhealthy fats. It's designed to be addictive and is often marketed to children. It's linked to chronic diseases, cognitive behavioral issues, and even violence and conflict. It's a major contributor to the negative consequences of the current food environment.

title: Processed Foods and Disease
content: Academics, doctors, health professionals have no clue how powerful food is to heal disease. We have a real lack of understanding of the power of food to cause disease and the power of food to cure disease. Something like medicare for all would bankrupt the country, says Mark, “because everybody’s sick and it’s going to bankrupt the country unless we fix why they’re sick in the first place.”

title: The Metabolic Difficulty of Processed Foods
content: Our biology isn’t adapted to eating highly refined foods. Yet, it’s ~60% of our calories. And every 10% of your calories that’s ultra processed food, your risk of death goes up by 14%. And that’s not to mention other stuff in processed foods and industrial farmed produce that may be problematic like refined soybean oil, food additives, chemicals, BPA from plastics, other metabolic toxins, pesticides and glyphosate affecting our microbiome. Sugar and starch and flour are the big drivers, but there’s all these other components. And then who knows what’s happening with pesticides and glyphosate affecting our microbiome. I mean it’s such a complex web of different factors that alter our metabolic pathways that drives disease.

title: The Impact of Refined Starches and Sugars on Biology
content: Refined starches and sugars affect your biology: They raise insulin, which has a cascading effect of fat storage in your belly, which is a dangerous fat. It leads to increased hunger, affects your brain chemistry. It actually locks the fat in the fat cells so that can’t get out. It slows your metabolism. So you’re in this cascade of vicious cycles.

title: Energy Balance vs. Nutrients and Fiber
content: How much of the problem with processed food is about a lack of nutrients and fiber vs. an energy balance problem? Probably both, says Mark. It’s well known that if you are looking for nutrients, you’re just going to eat anything (e.g., kids with Pica will eat dirt). Most people think about calories in, calories out. But it’s more complex than that. There’s different effects of food on your biology, independent of calories. 750 calories of Coke is NOT the same as 750 calories of broccoli, for example, they have profoundly different effects on your biology. But we don’t really appreciate that medicine and most of our current thinking about weight loss is focused on calories in, calories out.

title: The Food Industry and the 'Calories In, Calories Out' Narrative
content: The Food industry loves to push the “calories in, calories out” narrative. They say, “it’s all about moderation. There’s no good or bad calories. It’s exercise more, eat less.” But the truth is that these foods affect our brain chemistry and create all sorts of metabolic issues that are incredibly difficult. Neurologist David Perlmutter just wrote a book called Brain Wash, which explains the prefrontal cortex and the amygdala are uncoupled with an inflammatory diet. The prefrontal cortex, which is the decision maker, understands the consequences of his behavior, is not talking to the amygdala which is the impulse part of your brain (the fight or flight part of your brain, the pleasure seeking part of the brain).

title: Inflammation and processed food
content: We have so much bad behavior and conflict and so forth because we’re eating this inflammatory diet that’s literally dysregulating our brains. So the adult in the room is asleep. But anyone will do better when eating a whole foods, unprocessed diet. Processed foods drive up insulin which leads to visceral belly fat. Mark calls this a “metabolic fire” that starts in these cells and it spreads inflammation throughout the body.

title: Inflammatory biomarkers
content: Mark says our current tools for assessing the immune response to food are “pretty crappy”. Fortunately, there’s this whole new panel of inflammatory biomarkers that are much more specific and much more sensitive and it enables us to really look at the inflammatory response that’s happening in the body (see Buck Institute of Aging).

title: Gut microbiome and inflammation
content: Peter admits that there current protocol for trying to fix subtle elevations in fibrinogen and/or C reactive protein or at least two of the interleukins is “crude”. It’s basically a elimination diet where you take thing away and keep an eye on the biomarkers. One possibility is gut permeability. It’s a huge source, says Mark. All our guts are messed up. There’s a well-studied phenomenon called metabolic endotoxemia. The gut microbiome has a huge role in regulation of weight (independent of calories). Our low fiber, high sugar, high processed food diets increase bad bugs in the gut. Antibiotics, acid blockers, antiinflammatory drugs, hormones all screw up our gut as well. And environmental toxins, such as glyphosate, is super toxic to the microbiome. They start to disrupt the gut microbiome. They disrupt the lining of the gut. This allows the absorption of bacterial products, bacterial toxins as well as food antigens. And they start to create an inflammatory response. This is partly a problem because about 60% of your immune system is in your gut. At least a third of our metabolites in our blood may be from microbiome. And these non-human bacteria that are regulating your immune system, activating your mitochondria, regulating your DNA, affecting your brain chemistry (mood), and affecting all sorts of diseases. This is like a really exciting area and I think getting people’s microbiome sorted often happens when you shift to a whole-foods, plant-rich diet.

title: Measuring gut health
content: It’s a challenge because you are looking at a moving target, an ecosystem” says Mark. Many different biomarkers to assess what’s going on in the gut. Is there adequate pancreatic enzyme function looking at pancreatic elastase? Are there absorption issues? Looking at fecal fats, are there inflammatory markers in there? For example, calprotectin or eosinophil protein X, which are standard markers to look at inflammation in the gut. What’s your IGA levels, your antibody levels? Indicators of dysregulated gut microbiome – such as low levels of short chain fatty acids. Short chain FA are essentially produced by good bacteria that are the fuel for the gut.

title: Nutrition and Gut Health
content: They have anticancer & antiinflammatory properties. Example would be having low levels of butyrate. You can also look for different microbiome characteristics using DNA, or PCR analysis through the microRNAs. For example, levels of Akkermansia. You can also look at gut culture for parasites (PCR testing). Steps to fixing a bad gut—The Five R’s [24:30].

title: The Five R's
content: Steps to fixing a bad gut—The Five R’s [24:30]. REMOVE. REPLACE. REINOCULATE. REPAIR. RESTORE. Step 1: Remove. Remove foods that may be triggering a problem like Gluten, which affects permeability, Dairy, Grains for some people. Remove “bad bugs”. Some people have a parasite (Mark recently gave a woman Alinia, antiparasitic medication, for six days and she felt better after suffering for 20 years). Other people may have bacterial overgrowth or yeast overgrowth that needs to be removed. Step 2: Replace. Replace what might be missing. Fiber, prebiotics, enzymes, various things that may be needed to support the system. You can take supplements or eat prebiotic foods like plantain and artichokes. Step 3: Reinoculate. Provide probiotics where necessary. And that can be through foods like fermented foods or can be through probiotic supplements. Step 4: Repair. The body may need certain nutrients to heal. Glutamine, Vitamin A, Fish oil, Butyrate, Polyphenols from food (pomegranate, cranberries, green tea, etc.). Step 5: Restore. Restore your nervous system, says Mark. For example, high stress levels can cause a leaky gut.

title: Staggering Health Statistics
content: Some staggering health statistics, and which races might be more genetically susceptible [27:15]. Some staggering statistics: (ref). 6 out of 10 Americans have a chronic disease. 4 out of 10 have two or more chronic diseases. In 10 years, 83 million Americans with have 3 or more. 1 in 2 Americans has prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. 75% of us are overweight. Most states now have 40% obesity rates. Are there genetic differences that make certain races of people more susceptible? Genetically, there’s certain segments of the population that are more susceptible to getting obesity and diabetes when they’re in an abundance of sugar and flour. That includes Native Americans (probably the most susceptible), African Americans, Latinos, South Pacific islanders, People from India, China, and Asians people often are at much higher risk even at lower body rates.

title: Government Regulations and Policies
content: An argument for government regulations and policies to fight back against a massive food industry with unlimited resources (and what we can learn from the tobacco story) [29:00]. Is there any country or government in particular that seems more attuned to this problem than the American government? “Many. In fact, most.” says Mark. ⇒ Chile, for example, is attempting to address the massive obesity rates in kids and adults and the staggering healthcare cost in the following ways: Taxing soda, Warning labels on bad food, No cartoon characters can be used to advertise to kids, eliminated any processed foods from school lunches, eliminated any advertising on junk food from 6am until 10pm, the restriction of food marketing and the warning label and so forth had a fourfold increased benefit compared to the soda tax. What can we learn from the successful campaign against smoking cigarettes? Some might argue the marketing restrictions would violate the First Amendment. The US has faced an analogous situation with smoking.

title: The successful fight against the tobacco industry
content: Prior to the Surgeon General saying publicly that cigarettes are causing lung cancer, about 55% of the people over 18 years smoked. That has dropped to about 16% currently. Peter brings this up as a “work around” rather than going down the fight against the First Amendment. Perhaps the successful fight against the tobacco industry offers a playbook that can be followed?

title: The food industry is stalling the regulations
content: Mark says that the food industry is actually copying the tobacco industry’s playbook to slow or stall or stop this. Example #1: Subversive tactics to avoid the soda taxes that passed in California. The American Beverage Association went to California and put in a ballot measure, which was designed to prohibit local taxes unless it was a two thirds majority. Next, at the last minute before the election, they went to Governor Jerry Brown and told him, “Look, we’ll pull this measure, but you have to put in place a preemptive law that prohibits any future taxes on soda or junk food.” This is exactly what tobacco did. Example #2: An initiative called the Global Energy Balance Network, GEBN. The GEBN’s mantra was that all calories were the same and it was simply about moderation and calories in/calories out. Rhona Applebaum (VP at Coca-Cola) ran GEBN and she found a bunch of scientists (like James Hill) who she could co-op, paid them lots of money, and funded research to actually promote the idea that all calories are the same. Eventually it was discovered what they were doing and the NY Times reported it. After the NY Times article came out they shut down the GEBN.

title: Should we try to solve this on the individual level instead of the government level?
content: Why not focus all of the efforts on helping individual people understand the harm of this food so that they can make the informed choice? Do we really believe that this has to be solved at the level that seems almost unwinnable, which is fighting an unethical opponent with infinite resources? Mark points out it worked against the tobacco industry. Peter: “But you don’t need tobacco to live, right?…The advantage that you would have as an anti-tobacco crusade person is the ground is not muddied by the notion that tobacco is part of a group called food that you need to live.” Would we be better off putting more effort into sort of the grassroots campaign to inform individuals versus using public policy? Mark says that we must do both.

title: Industrial farming and climate change
content: “Does fixing food fix climate? It does. It’s actually one of the only ways to really reverse climate change.” Some climate change stats: A million acres flooded in the Midwest, crop land, it’s destroying farmer’s livelihood. Increasing weather patterns of hurricanes and wildfires in Australia and California. Melting of three trillion tons of ice from Antarctica.

title: The Impact of Our Food System on Climate Change
content: Half of climate change comes from our food system through all sorts of different mechanisms: 1—Deforestation, you lose the carbon capture from the trees 2—Soil destruction from destructive agriculture. The industrial growing of food tills the soil and which disrupts the normal organic matter and causes soil erosion which releases carbon in the environment. Soil is probably the biggest cause and the biggest solution to fixing climate change. A third to 40% of all the carbon in the atmosphere today that’s causing climate volatility is from the loss of soil. When soil is alive, meaning it has living organic matter (including carbon) in it… It can hold three times the amount of carbon that’s in the atmosphere today (It can hold 3 trillion tons of carbon).

title: The Importance of Soil
content: Soil is alive ⇒ it has all kinds of bugs in it, mycorrhizal fungi, bacteria, and carbon in it from the plants. It also holds a huge amount of water. For every 1% organic matter can hold 27,000 gallons of water, which would prevent floods and droughts and create more resilient farms. Soil is like a sponge, so when it rains instead of the rain running off or running through, it gets stored like a sponge in the soil so that you don’t need to irrigate, that you don’t have to worry about floods and droughts. The difference between soil and dirt: Soil is alive, dirt is dead, by contrast. Dirt doesn’t hold water, it doesn’t have much carbon in it, and it doesn’t have much nutrients. Since we are growing food in dirt, we see 50% less nutrient density in food (even healthy food).

title: The Negative Impact of Fertilizer on Soil
content: Fertilizer is driving the destruction of our soil. There’s 400 billion pounds of fertilizer used everywhere in the world. It’s a seven fold increase over the last 40 years because they are only two thirds as effective as they used to be. The process of making fertilizer is itself very chemically intensive and uses energy. It’s the number one utilizer of fracking-produced natural gas, says Mark, and fracking releases methane into the atmosphere. Fertilizer companies, like Yara and Mosaic, they use more natural gas than Exxon. A methane leak in Ohio was recently so big you could see it from space. The methane from fertilizer uses to growing plants is a quarter of all methane released gas in the environment today (which is as much as factory farm cows).

title: Oil usage in food production
content: One fifth of all our oil consumption is for the food system. That’s more than all cars, planes, boats, transportation combined.

title: Purpose of fertilizer
content: The purpose of fertilizer is to provide nitrogen, phosphorus, and other nutrients to the plants.

title: Carbon fixation
content: Peter says, “I don’t think people appreciate the significance of carbon fixation.” It’s a complicated chemical reaction to take carbon and join it to carbon like a plant can do. First, it requires sunlight for this photosynthetic thing. But basically plants need carbon, which they’re getting from the air. Then they need nitrogen and phosphorus, which they’re getting from their soil. And they need energy and water, which they’re getting from the environment. And then they make biomass.

title: Historical fertilizer
content: Yes, says Mark, but most of the fertilizer that was growing plants historically came from either nitrogen fixing plants like the lagoons or from the animals. The reason we have 50 feet of top soil in some areas in this country, 150 years ago is because of all millions of bison running around. They’d be like bison and elk and all these ruminants that were running around in big herds, chomping things down, moving on to the next spot, peeing and pooping, saliva makes the grass grow. So it was this beautiful symbiotic system that built literally tens of feet of topsoil. Today, the problem is not that we have too many cows, it’s how we’re growing and farming them.

title: Explosion in crop yield
content: Today, the only metric that really “matters” is bushels per acre, per year. It all comes down to yield. Basically from the Civil War to about the end of World War II, if you look at crop yield and you see the plot, it was about 20 bushels per acre per year. At the end of World War II, yield began rising up to 200 bushels per acre, per year. Most people erroneously assume it was the GMO that was the reason for this. But in fact, GMO didn’t really even kick in until that number was 160 bushels per acre per year. The explosion in crop yield was a combination of nitrogen-based fertilizer, crop rotation, industrial farming, and selective breeding. So it was a bunch of things that came and then basically GMO has put like a ~10% plus up on that from a yield perspective. The point is this really began in earnest about 70 years ago and prior to 70 years ago it’s been remarkably flat. But post World War II we had to figure out how to feed a bunch of people and 20 bushels per acre per year was not cutting it. We’re now 10 times the yield, but it came at quite a cost (to health and climate, for example).

title: Regenerative agriculture
content: Mark says, “there’s sort of a fallacy in the idea that we can’t produce the same amount of food using regenerative methods”. The story of farmer, Gabe Brown: Gabe is a North Dakota farmer who has a 5,000 acre farm that was devastated by hail, devastated by weather, and was about to go bankrupt. He decided to try regenerative agriculture. He has now built 29 inches of soil. He uses no chemical inputs. He makes his own fertilizer from the animals as well as from the “nitrogen fixing” plants that he plants. The results? He produces more food, better quality food, and makes 20 times as much money as his neighbor.

title: Green revolution
content: “There’s this fallacy that we need green revolution, or that we need industrial agriculture to feed the world. . .That’s really what Monsanto (now Bayer) and a lot of these big agrochemical companies are saying because they are trying to push their products on the marketplace.”

title: Regenerative agriculture and climate change
content: Regenerative agriculture can help mitigate climate change by interrupting problems that drive climate change, such as factory-made fertilizer. Factory-made fertilizer damages the soil and releases nitrous oxide, which is 300 times more potent than greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide. Additionally, it runs off into rivers, streams, and lakes, creating dead zones and killing fish. Using organic nitrogen sources, such as animal poop, can help keep nitrogen in the soil and prevent runoff. Other climate-damaging factors from industrial farming include deforestation, soil damage, transportation, refrigeration, processing, distribution, and food waste.

title: Food waste
content: Humans waste 30-40% of our food, which is a big cost. We waste food in the developed world by throwing out food in our kitchen and losing food in the food chain because of lack of storage and transportation, refrigeration.

title: Obstacles to regenerative agriculture
content: The $15 trillion food industry that's dependent on the products of industrial farming is an obstacle to moving towards regenerative agriculture. They sell the seeds, the fertilizer, the pesticides, and herbicides. Farmers are caught between big ag and the government, who is telling them to produce certain foods and supporting them to do it. However, that money then goes to buy the seed, the glyphosate, and other agrochemicals from Monsanto and fertilizer from Yara.

title: Regenerative agriculture and struggling farmers
content: Regenerative agriculture can be the answer for struggling farmers. The average farmer loses $1,600 per year, and they are caught between big ag and the government. However, regenerative agriculture techniques can be easily applied and are done in millions of acres around the world with great benefit and high productivity and mitigating climate at the same time. The transition to regenerative agriculture can take three to five years.

title: Regenerative agriculture and climate change
content: We need a massive effort for supporting and transforming our agricultural system to regenerative ag. The climate solution is multifaceted, but it includes restoring degraded lands. Is regenerative ag the top solution to climate change? Mark says that regenerative ag is the top solution to climate change and it’s being overlooked. It’s been estimated by some that we could draw down anywhere from 30 to a 100% of all the carbon that’s been released since the industrial revolution, if we can scale this up.

title: Counter arguments to regenerative agriculture
content: One is that we NEED industrial agriculture to feed the world. Another counter comes from the vegan community who says this won’t fix the climate. Pat Brown from Impossible Foods, for example, has been really clearly stating that we need to get rid of all meat. And that even regenerative meat doesn’t work in terms of protecting the environment. Mark says that Pat quotes various studies that were flawed and miss a lot of the data.

title: Regenerative agriculture adds value back into the earth
content: Regenerative ag ADDS value back into the earth rather than taking value. It takes time, but there’s an incredible value chain that gets put in place. We take out of the earth about $125 trillion in natural capital (more than global GDP). We don’t put it back and it’s running out. For example, Farmland LP is a private equity company that’s buying up conventional farms, converting them to regenerative agriculture, and moving those farms from single digit profits to high double digit. They are leveraging “ecosystem services”. Another example is Costa Rica, they are paying for ecosystem services for their farmers in order to produce more soil, conserve water, increase biodiversity, etc.

title: Comparison of Impossible Burger to regeneratively raised beef
content: The Impossible Burger is a GMO, soy-based product. Quantis did an analysis looking at the impossible burger compared to regeneratively raised beef burger. The impossible burger was far better than a conventional factory farm burger, but it added three and a half kilos of carbon for every burger you ate. The factory farmed burger added about 50 kilos of carbon.

title: GMO and Roundup
content: The potential health risks of consuming GMO foods sprayed with Roundup (glyphosate) and other herbicides and pesticides. GMO stands for “Genetically modified organism”. Many crops, corn for example, can be genetically modified so that they are resistant to the effects of glyphosate (Roundup) which is an herbicide (weed-killer). That way, the plants will survive getting sprayed but the weeds will die. Why might GMOs be problematic? First, it MIGHT be harmful to be eating an organism that now has a gene that looks different from the gene that we evolved to consume it. Secondly, it enables the use of chemicals (e.g., RoundUp/glyphosate) in a higher concentration than you would be able to use them in the absence of genetic modifications to the plant. In other words, the food is getting exposed to Roundup (glyphosate) and it may be harmful for people to be consuming that. Glyphosate is now ~70% of the agrochemicals used on the planet and it’s increasingly being linked to harmful human effects.

title: Glyphosate and Microbiome
content: Another study where glyphosate disrupts the microbiome in significant ways in animals. And in one impossible burger there is 110 times the dose that was used in the animal studies to totally disrupt the microbiome of the rats. Peter rebuts, “But do we know how bioavailable it is and how much it remains?” Mark, “Well, it’s on the food.”

title: Glyphosate and Industrial Agriculture
content: Mark takes a precautionary approach to glyphosate, which is found in most humans. He believes that industrial agriculture is not the best way to grow food and poses potential risks. Farmers are getting squeezed by big ag companies, which is causing economic consequences and increasing suicides. The UN estimated that $300 billion could solve the problem of climate change and give us 20 years more runway to solve the bigger issues.

title: Loss of Biodiversity in Our Food
content: We’ve lost 90% of our edible plant species, 60% of our calories come from 12 species, and we’ve lost half our livestock species. We have lost 75% of our pollinator species on which agriculture depends. Butterflies, pollinators, all damaged also by these pesticides and chemicals that are indiscriminate in what they kill.

title: Chemicals Killing the Soil
content: The chemicals that we use in the soil and the farming methods we use are destroying the soil which is an incredible diverse ecosystem. We’re running out of these bio-diverse animals that are essential for our health and our survival. It’s about individual choices, business innovations, and policy to bring back biodiversity.

title: What Does Organic Mean?
content: Organic is a certification that’s delivered by the government which means no antibiotics, no pesticides, no herbicides. However, it doesn’t certify the method of growing the food. In Michael Pollan’s book, Omnivore’s Dilemma, he talked about how “industrial organic” is better than industrial farming, but it’s not fully regenerative.

title: Regenerative farming and organic certification
content: Regenerative is the method of farming that actually includes organic but goes beyond it. There is now a proposal to create a regenerative organic certification which may eventually be turned into a food label.

title: Organic meat and regenerative farming
content: Organic meat generally means no hormones or antibiotics were used AND that it’s not using the chemical inputs on the corn fed to the animals. However, organic doesn’t necessarily mean that the animals weren’t fed “orangic” food that is grown in ways that are destroying the soil. That’s why regenerative is sort of organic plus.

title: Individual actions for a better food system
content: Things people can do: Being really focused on what you eat and where it comes from. Buy from a local farmer’s market. Joining a community support that supports agriculture. Looking for regenerative sources online. Bulk buying things together with friends. Maybe you should have a compost pile. Make a compost box. You can go in your municipality and say to your local government and say “let’s have a composting law”. You can push for creating economic incentives related to food waste.

title: Food waste and its impact
content: Many dairy farmers are making less money and struggling. One dairy farmer created these anaerobic digesters which gets food waste every week from grocery stores, mix it with the manure from the animals, and this “digester” combusts and produces electricity for 1,500 homes and makes the farmer an extra a hundred grand a year. Food waste is an incredible problem. 30 or 40% of all food producers wasted. The average family throws out about a pound a day or about $1,800 a year of food. This much food in a landfill would create greenhouse gases that would be the third largest emitter of greenhouse gases (after the US and China). The Trump Administration has already created a food waste initiative where the EPA, FDA, and the USDA are going to actually deal with the food waste issue.

title: USDA and its role in the toxic food environment
content: At the high level, the USDA is responsible for a number of different food and ag policies that are “messed up”. Our dietary guidelines. Our school lunch guidelines. SNAP program (aka Food stamp program). 75 billion a year. Feeds 46 million Americans (1 in 4 kids). $7 billion a year just in soda (about 30 billion servings a year). There’s no nutritional guidelines. In fact, you can buy anything except alcohol and cooked food. So you can buy a two liter bottle of soda, but you can’t buy a rotisserie chicken in the grocery store! 75% of the food stamps goes towards junk food or soda! Then you have crop insurance and agricultural supports that support harmful a industrial agricultural system. For example, if you have a big soy and corn farm and you want to grow a whole bunch of veggies, you can’t, even if you want to because you will get penalized and not get your crop insurance. So farmers are disincentivized from growing fruits and vegetables.

title: Lack of Government Support for Fruits and Vegetables
content: The government tells us on the one hand, eat half of our plate as fruits and vegetables, but less than half a percent of agricultural supports from the government are for fruits and vegetables. It’s like basically if we were eating what the government actually funded in agricultural supports, we’d be having a giant corn fritter, deep fried in soybean oil. And it’s like, that’s not exactly what we should be eating.

title: Toxic Substances in Our Food Supply
content: It allows substances that are banned in other countries that are toxic to be in our food supply. Example being azodicarbonamide, which is basically a softener for flour products for bread. In Singapore, you get a $450,000 fine and you go to jail for 15 years for using azodicarbonamide.

title: The Need for a National Food Policy
content: We need a national food policy. We need activism to change some of these food policies. We need support for regenerative ag. We need to reform food stamps and school lunches. And we need to help advance the health care system to promote “food is medicine.”

title: Mark's Top 3 Changes as 'Food Czar'
content: 1 | Immediately transform healthcare reimbursement to focus on food as medicine through paying for food. Reimbursing fruit and vegetable prescriptions. Making food a central part of the government such as having them only purchase food that is going to promote health and not disease. 2 | Reform these dysfunctional food policies. Transform SNAP. Transform school lunches. Transform the dietary guidelines to be science-based. 3 | Support regenerative ag in every way possible. Through government policies. Business innovations. Economic incentives.

title: The Need for Animals in Regenerative Agriculture
content: We need animals for the soil (even if you don’t eat them). Without animals integrated into regenerative agricultural systems, you cannot restore soil in the way we need to restore it as fast as we need to restore it. Pooping, peeing, digging, and even their saliva makes the plants grow. With proper management (aka holistic management, or managed grazing, or adaptive multi-paddock grazing)… “you can dramatically increase soil”, says Mark. Some say it takes a thousand years to get three centimeters of soil naturally.

title: Regenerative Agriculture and Nutrition
content: Mark discusses the importance of regenerative agriculture in solving global issues. He emphasizes the need to scale this model to solve issues such as climate change. He also mentions that animals must be integrated into the process to restore soil, which is the biggest carbon sink.

title: Mark's Mission
content: Mark's high-level goal is to end suffering through the power of functional medicine, systems thinking, and restoring communities. He believes that unless we deal with the systems issues, we're just going to be treading water or bailing a sinking boat. He also mentions that food is the biggest threat to climate change.

title: Bread in the US vs. Europe
content: Peter observed that bread and wheat products in Europe did not seem to produce the same negative effect as those same foods in America. Mark explains that this is due to a complex web of factors, including the hybridization of wheat in the US to make it extremely drought resistant and hardy, the creation of gliadin proteins, and the use of glyphosate at harvest.

title: Glyphosate in Cheerios
content: Your Cheerios have more glyphosate than vitamin A and vitamin D in their per amount of weight. Organic wheat is not sprayed with glyphosate. However, it could still be the dwarf wheat.

title: Calcium Procreate
content: Calcium procreate is a preservative which is added to the wheat in the US. It’s known to cause toxic neurological effects, behavioral hyperactivity, and has been linked to autism (at least in animal models).

title: Quick Rising Bread in the US
content: In the US, our breads rise in a couple hours. In Europe, it can take 12 hours to 14 hours. It tastes very different and it’s a very different structure. It does different things to the gluten.

title: Alternative Wheat Options
content: Better wheats include heirloom wheats, einkorn wheat, Kernza grain by The Land Institute, and Himalayan buckwheat. These options are much better for us, but we just kind of homogenized our food supply.
